title: U.S. Stock Futures Drop After Fed; Crude Steadies: Markets Wrap
text:
(Bloomberg) -- U.S. stock futures fell while Europe shares advanced with the euro as the dust settled from the Federal Reserve rate cut, and investor focus turned to a slew of other central bank decisions. The yen jumped after a Bank of Japan policy decision.

Construction-company shares and banks led the Europe Stoxx 600 higher, while contracts on the three main U.S. equity indexes dropped. Hong Kong shares fell, Shanghai equities edged up and China’s yuan dropped as traders weighed the odds of the People’s Bank of China lowering borrowing costs.

Treasuries climbed while European government bonds slipped. The yen rose the most in three weeks after the BOJ left its policy settings unchanged while noting rising risks. The pound nudged higher before the Bank of England’s policy decision Thursday. The Swiss National Bank held its policy rate and deposit rate at minus 0.75%, and the franc strengthened.

Thursday’s slate of policy decisions, hot on the heels of the Fed cut, provide fresh clues as to how far the world’s central banks are willing to go to support growth amid soft economic data and trade uncertainty. The BOJ failed to follow the Fed and European Central Bank in easing policy, but said it will “reexamine” growth and price developments.

Investors will look for signs last week’s show of goodwill is gaining momentum as U.S.-China trade deputies meet Thursday and Friday in Washington ahead of higher-level meetings in mid-October. The geopolitical situation in the Middle East remains unclear after Saudi Arabia blamed Iran for last Saturday’s attack on its oil installations, an event which is helping inflame tension between America and the Islamic Republic.

“There’s no cohesive narrative” at the moment, said Hannah Anderson, a global market strategist at JPMorgan Asset Management. The Fed rate cut and briefing by its chairman “doesn’t really change the narrative that investors are going to need more than that from some governing body to give a central thesis that they feel comfortable sticking with for a while,” she said.

Elsewhere, crude oil futures were steady and gold was little changed. Australia’s dollar slumped after the unemployment rate rose. Norway’s central bank delivered its fourth interest-rate increase in a year, while policy makers in Indonesia cut interest rates for third month in row.

These are some key events to keep an eye on this week:

Bank of England decides monetary policy Thursday.Friday is quadruple witching day for U.S. markets. When the quarterly expiration of futures and options on indexes and stocks occurs on the same day, surging volatility and trading can follow.

Here are the main moves in markets:

Stocks

Futures on the S&P 500 Index fell 0.2% as of 9:24 a.m. London time.The Stoxx Europe 600 Index increased 0.2%.Germany’s DAX Index jumped 0.3%.The U.K.’s FTSE 100 Index climbed 0.2%.The MSCI Asia Pacific Index declined 0.1%.

Currencies

The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 0.1%.The euro climbed 0.3% to $1.1058.The British pound gained 0.1% to $1.2479.The Japanese yen rose 0.4% to 108.03 per dollar.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasuries decreased three basis points to 1.77%.Britain’s 10-year yield gained less than one basis point to 0.645%.Germany’s 10-year yield rose two basis points to -0.49%.

Commodities

Gold gained 0.2% to $1,497.03 an ounce.West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.5% to $58.42 a barrel.Brent crude climbed 0.7% to $64.05 a barrel.
